docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: You attribute the soaring costs of health insurance premiums in part to the ''biomedical revolution'' and to doctors' and patients' resistance to managed care's restrictions (front page, Aug. 11). But the recent rise in premiums may also be explained as a natural outcome of their artificial depression in prior decades.

headline.main: The Rising Cost of Health Care

keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: ImClone Systems filed suit yesterday against its indicted founder and former chief executive, Samuel D. Waksal, seeking to recover more than $7 million in severance and other compensation. The company said in its complaint, filed in New York State Supreme Court, that it wanted to retrieve the money because Mr. Waksal had falsely assured company executives and directors that he was cooperating with federal investigators.

headline.main: ImClone Sues Former Chief To Recover $7 Million

docs.abstract: ImClone Systems sues founder-former chief executive Samuel D Waksal, seeking to recover more than $7 million in severance and other compensation; wants to retrieve money because Waksal falsely assured company executives and directors that he was cooperating with federal investigators (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Conseco, the big financial services company that is teetering on the brink of bankruptcy, said yesterday that its accounting was under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company, which is struggling with $6.5 billion in debt, also reported a net loss of $1.33 billion, or $3.86 a share, for the second quarter, nearly four times the loss of $30.3 million, or 9 cents a share, it reported in the period a year earlier. It was the fifth consecutive quarterly loss for the company.

headline.main: To Add to Conseco's Woes, U.S. Is Looking at Its Accounting

docs.abstract: Conseco, which is on brink of bankruptcy, says its accounting is under investigation by Securities and Exchange Commission; company, which is struggling with $6.5 billion in debt, also reports net loss of $1.33 billion for second quarter compared with loss of $30.3 million year earlier; SEC probe centers on events in spring of 2000 and earlier when chief executive was Stephen Hilbert; chief executive Gary C Wendt comments; Conseco's ratings are downgraded by A M Best (M)

docs.abstract: Dr Philip Pollner letter, commenting on August 11 letter, questions why lawmakers seem incapable of finding ways of providing health insurance for 40 million Americans who lack it, noting they provide premiums for themselves through taxes
